metadata.Title: CVE-2015-3152 on Ubuntu 14.04 ESM (trusty) - low.
metadata.Description:
Oracle MySQL before 5.7.3, Oracle MySQL Connector/C (aka libmysqlclient) before 6.1.3, and MariaDB before 5.5.44 use the --ssl option to mean that SSL is optional, which allows man-in-the-middle attackers to spoof servers via a cleartext-downgrade attack, aka a "BACKRONYM" attack.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2015-3152` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

libmariadbclient18 - 5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1
mariadb-client - 5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1
mariadb-client-5.5 - 5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1
mariadb-client-core-5.5 - 5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1
mariadb-common - 5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1
mariadb-server - 5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1
mariadb-server-5.5 - 5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1
mariadb-server-core-5.5 - 5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1
mariadb-test - 5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1
mariadb-test-5.5 - 5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1
No subscription required

notes.Note: tyhicks> The MySQL documentation makes the behavior of the --ssl option clear. It isn't known if they'll release updates for the 5.5/5.6 series. mdeslaur> not included in 5.5.47 or 5.6.28. Marking this issue as "ignored" since it doesn't look like upstream is going to fix this in 5.5 and 5.6, and we aren't going to diverge from upstream.

criterions.comment: mariadb-5.5 package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '5.5.44-1ubuntu0.14.04.1').
mysql-5.5: while related to the CVE in some way, a decision has been made to ignore this issue.
mysql-5.6: while related to the CVE in some way, a decision has been made to ignore this issue.
percona-xtradb-cluster-5.5: while related to the CVE in some way, a decision has been made to ignore this issue (note: 'end of standard support').
